G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant conducts business in Middlesex County and the incident occurred at Defendant’s store located at 214 Market Street, Lowell, Massachusetts.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty to exercise reasonable care in the maintenance, operation, and inspection of its store premises. (See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 931 N.E.2d 142 (2010)).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the traditional rule that a property owner owes invitees a duty to use reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe, including by repairing, removing, or warning of dangerous conditions—this is the exact duty described in the proposition. The court then applies that general premises-liability standard to hazards from snow and ice, confirming that business property owners like Target owe lawful visitors (including business invitees) a duty of reasonable care in maintaining, operating, and inspecting the premises.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: If the plaintiff was an invitee, defined as a person invited onto the property by the property owner for the property owner’s benefit, ... the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” … This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious… .

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 863 N.E.2d 1276 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that heavy items stacked improperly and without safety precautions created a foreseeable risk of harm to customers. (*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 863 N.E.2d 1276 (2007)).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The case concerns a grape on the floor in a self-service grocery store and adopts the mode-of-operation approach for slip-and-fall hazards created by customers. It does not address heavy items, stacking practices, or safety precautions related to stacking. The court’s reasoning is limited to foreseeability of debris/spillage (like fruit and vegetables) on the floor in a self-service setting, so using this case to support a proposition about improperly stacked heavy items misstates its holding.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer, and a reasonably prudent person would not place these items in an aisle or allow them to remain there. Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 139 N.E..proposition: Negligence requires a showing of duty, breach, causation, and damages: *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 139 N.E.2d 451 (2006).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 139 N.E..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim, listing duty, breach, damage, and causal relation between breach and damage. This directly matches the proposition that negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages, and the court cites a tort treatise as authority for that formulation.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 139 N.E..relevant_excerpt: "3. Negligence claim, a. Duty of care, generally. To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005)."

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 670 N.E.2d 383 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Foreseeability as a key element of negligence: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 670 N.E.2d 383 (1996).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the "reasonably foreseeable risk of harm" created by the defendant’s negligence, showing that foreseeability is a central part of the negligence/causation analysis in this case. Although the excerpt is limited and focuses on disagreement about causation doctrine and prior key-in-ignition cases, the concurrence clearly treats foreseeability of harm as a necessary element in assessing negligence liability, which aligns with the proposition that foreseeability is a key element of negligence.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: I concur in the view that "[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence." Ante at 640-641.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 297.proposition: Reasonable care standard: *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 297 N.E.2d 43 (1973).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 297.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case that abolishes the invitee/licensee distinction and adopts a general reasonable care standard owed by land possessors to lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage criticizes retaining special treatment for trespassers, but it is consistent with and premised on the majority’s move to a reasonable care framework. Although this excerpt is from a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the case as a whole is appropriately cited for the proposition that the reasonable care standard governs landowner liability to entrants (at least lawful ones).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 297.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

*Basile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*,.raw_text: *Basile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*, 632 N.E.2d 848 (Mass. App. Ct. 1994)
*Basile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*,.proposition: The “mode of operations” rule: *Basile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*, 632 N.E.2d 848 (Mass. App. Ct. 1994).
*Basile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns criminal sexual assault convictions and evidentiary issues about fresh complaint testimony, not premises liability or store “mode of operation” rules. Nowhere does the court discuss slip-and-fall standards, self-service retail operations, or any doctrine resembling a “mode of operations” rule. Citing this case for that tort proposition is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
*Basile v. Stop & Shop Supermarket Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: In reviewing the admissibility of fresh complaint evidence, the test we apply is “whether the victim’s actions were reasonable in the particular circumstances.” Commonwealth v. McDonough, 400 Mass. 639, 652 (1987). See Liacos, Massachusetts Evidence § 6.18.2, at 341-342 (6th ed. 1994). Our courts “have not insisted on great promptness for fresh complaints in prosecutions involving child sexual abuse,” Commonwealth v. Amirault, 404 Mass. 221, 228-229 (1989) ...
